awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Optimizing Ion Mobility Spectrometry for Distributed Chemical Sensing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project seeks to produce a high performance, low power, electronic chemical sensor system that does not require a radioactive ionization source. Achieving a low cost, non-radioactive Internet of Things (IoT) systems for chemical sensing in a more distributed and connected network has potentially far reaching implications in many industries. Creating an IoT network of sensors to safely monitor chemical signatures on a large and distributed scale, in real-time, may provide new analytical-quality chemical sensing capabilities. Sensor applications may range from engineering (monitoring fermentations) and to health care (diagnostics), to environmental monitoring (air quality) and defense and security (hazard detection) or agriculture (waste mitigation). The chemical sampling and sensor platform has the potential to be integrated with cell phones and autonomous systems. The market for personal use devices could be substantial.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to establish an experimental and theoretical framework to optimize Differential Mobility Spectrometry (DMS) for analytical quality chemical identification. There are many types of chemical sensors that have been commercialized but no high-quality systems meet the performance, safety, and cost constraints required to be a successfully linked in an IoT system. The fundamental physics and commercial utility of DMS is well established, so it is a leading candidate for this use. The foundation of the system is a miniaturized DMS. Because the microchip operates on lithium ion polymer batteries, it has the potential for widely dispersed IoT-linked chemical sensing but the reliance on radioactive isotopes for chemical ionization is a critical barrier to adoption that limits commercial applications. This technical barrier may be overcome by combining a non-radioactive, plasma-based method of chemical ionization. The experimental results will be used to validate custom software to simulate performance of this complex system. If the performance of the combined system can be successfully modeled, it can be further miniaturized and optimized. The detection of natural gas odorants and selected food and flavor compounds have been selected as initial proof-of-concept commercial applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Overview: The environment is rich with chemical information in the form of trace gases. We seek to automate gas phase chemical sensing through proprietary devices with internet-linked systems and edge computing. Such a tool must generate, transmit, and process new information in the existing backbone of real time cloud services and data analytics to support human decisions. We can only unlock new utility with fundamentally new sensor hardware that gets at the chemicals the world is made of and connects that information to users in real time. The internet does many things well but it can't smell. 

Intellectual Merit: During our Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project we established an experimental and theoretical framework to optimize Differential Mobility Spectrometry (DMS) for analytical quality chemical identification. There are many types of chemical sensors that have been commercialized but no high-quality systems meet the performance, safety, and cost constraints required to be a successfully linked in an IoT system. The fundamental physics and commercial utility of DMS is well established and therefore a leading candidate for this use. The foundation of our system is a miniaturized DMS (1/2IMS). Because our proprietary 1/2IMS is a microchip that operates on lithium ion polymer batteries, it has the potential for widely dispersed IoT-linked chemical sensing. However, its reliance on radioactive isotopes for chemical ionization is a critical barrier to adoption that severely limits commercial applications.   This technical barrier was overcome in our Phase I work by combining a non-radioactive method of chemical ionization from MicroPlasma Systems LLC (MicroPlasma) with the SensIT Ventures, Inc. (SensIT) 1/2IMS. The innovation of our proposal is in combining these early stage systems in Phase I into a first commercial prototype. Because the performance of the combined system was successfully modeled, it can be further miniaturized and optimized. We chose to detect natural gas odorants as one initial proof-of-concept application. Natural gas is composed of the potent greenhouse gas methane (70-90%), a significant contributor to global warming. Because the gas is odorless and explosive, Federal regulations require that various sulfur containing compounds be added as an odorant blend such that 1/5 the level of the lower explosion limit would be "readily detectable" by a person with a "normal sense of smell." In conversations with the gas industry we understand that continuous, real-time monitoring would enable a range of improved safety and pollution monitoring services not currently feasible or economical. We also collected a representative library of DMS spectra using compounds selected from volatile anesthetics and from a test set of chemicals posted by a major technology company in the smart phone market with an interest in olfactory research. The ultimate commercial breakthrough would be to link precision chemical sensors to personal use electronics considering that about 80% of the world's population is connected to a smart phone.

Broader Impacts: The combined platforms of SensIT and MicroPlasma will yield the only high performance electronic chemical sensor system that does not require an AC power source or a radioactive ionization source. Achieving low-cost, non-radioactive, IoT systems for chemical sensing in a more distributed and connected network has far reaching implications in many industries. The ability to provide an IoT network of sensors to safely monitor chemical signatures on a large and distributed scale, in real-time, will provide an analytical quality chemical sensing capability that hasn't previously existed. If our design optimization allows for the identification of natural gas odorants comparable to a human olfactory system, our metric for success will improve safety and also help reduce methane pollution as a potent greenhouse gas.  If useful chemical sensing became a routine smartphone accessory function, it will be as transformative as the addition of digital cameras.

 


Last Modified: 09/17/2024
Modified by: Thomas Turpen
